Fig. 1 Schematic illustration of the oil transesterification for biodiesel synthesis. Fig 1 Fig. 2 (a) Effect of sulphonation duration on JCO transesterification efficiency, (b) PXRD analysis, and (c) FT-IR analysis for mango leaf, MLHC and MLCM-18-S. Fig 2 Fig. 3 Representative SEM images (a-c) of prepared MLCM-18-S catalyst, scale bars: (a) 500 μm, (b) 10 μm, (c) 1 μm; elemental mapping showing presence of (d) carbon, (e) oxygen, (f) sulphur, EDX analysis of (g) MLCM-18-S catalyst, (h) mango leaf and (i) MLHC. Fig 3 Fig. 4 (a) TGA analysis, (b) N2 adsorption-desorption isotherm, and (c) BJH pore size distribution curve for the mango leaf, MLHC and MLCM-18-S catalyst. Fig 4 Fig. 5 (a) 1H-NMR and (b) 13C-NMR of the product biodiesel. Fig 5 Fig. 6 (a) FT-IR and (b) gas chromatography analysis of the product biodiesel. Growing concerns over fossil fuel depletion and environmental impact have intensified the search for sustainable biofuels such as biodiesel. To address the drawbacks of homogeneous catalysts, a novel heterogeneous catalyst (MLCM-18-S) was developed via hydrothermal carbonization of mango leaf powder followed by sulfonation. This carbonaceous catalyst was employed for biodiesel production from non-edible Jatropha curcas oil. Under optimized conditions (methanol to oil ratio 21:1, 90 °C, 7.5 wt. % catalyst, 56 min of microwave irradiation), a high yield of 95.1 % biodiesel was achieved. The catalyst was thoroughly characterized using FTIR, XRD, SEM, BET and TGA, while the biodiesel was analysed by FTIR, NMR, and GC-MS. TGA demonstrated improved stability after hydrothermal treatment of mango leaf (weight loss reduced from 54.5 % to 40.2 % up to 470 °C), while the sulfonated catalyst (MLCM-18-S) showed only 7.0 % loss of –SO3H groups below 180 °C, confirming structural integrity under biodiesel reaction conditions. BET analysis confirmed the structural evolution from raw mango leaves (0.62 m2 g–1, 0.001 cc g–1), to a porous hydrochar (5.16 m2 g–1, 0.010 cc g–1), while sulfonation yielded a micro–mesoporous catalyst (MLCM-18-S) with hierarchical pores (∼1.8–16 nm) and abundant –SO3H groups. Kinetic studies revealed pseudo first order behaviour with an activation energy of 16.53 kJ mol–1. The catalyst exhibited excellent stability, retaining high activity up to the 5th reuse cycle. This study highlights the effectiveness of sustainable biomass derived catalysts for efficient and economically viable biodiesel production. Graphical abstract Image, graphical abstract Keywords Waste mango leaves Biodiesel Transesterification Cost analysis Sulphonation Carbonaceous material Jatropha curcas oil Data availability No data was used for the research described in the article. 1 Introduction The multiplicative expansion of the human population globally associated with the affluent living standards has given rise to in an exponential escalation in energy requirements. Currently, the major part of this energy is consumed by the movement of goods and services, which plays a key role in driving the global economy. It predominantly depends on non-replenishable fossil energy sources. In total primary energy consumption, the energy derived from petroleum resources is about 80 % of the overall total primary energy consumption. Amongst these, energy consumption done by the transportation sector is 54 % [1]. The natural formation of fossil fuels takes millions of years, and the increasing demand for energy has driven researchers to seek out a viable, ecofriendly, and sustainable alternative fuel. Consequently, biodiesel has grabbed attention worldwide and replaced fossil fuel to some extent. Biodiesel is renewable, biodegradable, nontoxic, carbon neutral and it comes with high combustion efficiency as well as low CO2 emission. Without much modification, a diesel engine can successfully run on biodiesel [2,3]. The main process used for biodiesel production is transesterification. These reactions involve various edible and non-edible oil feedstocks. In transesterification; homogeneous, heterogeneous, and enzymatic catalysts are used where the glycerol group of triacylglycerol (TAG) is reacted with an alcohol of short chain [4]. The diverse availability of feedstocks constitutes a major advantage for biodiesel production, supporting its role as a promising alternative to fossil fuels [1]. Among the various options, non-edible oils are often preferred over edible oils because they circumvent competition with food resources, lower production costs, and offer better sustainability prospects. Biodiesel derived from such non-edible sources is generally classified as a second generation biofuel, which also includes fuels produced from lignocellulosic biomass and waste oils [5]. Examples of non-edible oil bearing plants include Jatropha curcas, jojoba, rubber seed, tobacco seed, neem, sea mango, karanja, candlenut, yellow oleander, and mahua. Jatropha curcas oil, in particular, has been widely investigated due to its high fatty acid content and suitability for transesterification. Moreover, Jatropha can be cultivated on marginal or degraded lands, thereby avoiding competition with agricultural land for food production and contributing to soil restoration and ecosystem improvement [2]. Catalysts play a pivotal role in enhancing the transesterification reaction rate and reducing feedstock viscosity. Homogeneous catalysts such as sodium methoxide (NaOCH3), sodium hydroxide (NaOH), and potassium hydroxide (KOH) are inexpensive, highly soluble in the reaction medium, and capable of delivering high reaction rates under mild conditions. However, their application is limited by several drawbacks, including saponification in the presence of free fatty acids, difficulties in separating and purifying the products, large volumes of wastewater generated during washing, and the inability to recover and reuse the catalyst efficiently [6,7]. These limitations have driven increasing interest in heterogeneous catalysts, which offer advantages such as ease of separation from the reaction mixture, enhanced reusability, reduced environmental impact, and the ability to produce glycerol with higher purity. In addition, heterogeneous catalysts can often process feedstocks with higher free fatty acid content, tolerate a broader range of reaction conditions, and reduce the overall energy and chemical inputs required for biodiesel production [8,9]. Heterogeneous carbonaceous catalysts, widely explored for biodiesel production, can be synthesized through various thermochemical processes such as pyrolysis, gasification, and hydrothermal carbonization using diverse lignocellulosic biomass sources including corn cobs, rice husks, palm kernel shells, groundnuts, soybean shells, bamboo, palm seeds, pongamia seeds, and mango leaves [10]. These processes yield biochar or carbon based catalysts that possess desirable physicochemical properties such as high surface area, well developed porosity, thermal stability, chemical inertness, and surface modifiability, all of which are crucial for efficient catalytic activity [11,12]. Further enhancement of catalytic performance is achieved by employing carbonization, activation (physical or chemical), and surface functionalization techniques–often introducing acidic or basic groups that improve reactivity and selectivity toward transesterification reactions [13]. These carbonaceous catalysts have demonstrated excellent potential in promoting high biodiesel yields while maintaining sustainability and cost–effectiveness, making them viable alternatives to conventional catalysts in green fuel production. The present study reports the synthesis of a sulfonated carbon based catalyst derived from mango leaves, an abundant and low cost biomass resource. The catalyst was prepared via hydrothermal treatment, followed by sulfonation using concentrated sulfuric acid to introduce –SO3H functional groups. Sulfonated carbon catalysts are widely recognized as efficient solid acid catalysts for transesterification reactions, owing to their strong acidity, stability, reusability, and environmentally benign nature. These characteristics make them particularly effective for converting diverse feedstocks into biodiesel. Biodiesel is typically produced via the transesterification of triglycerides, a process conventionally conducted using thermal heating methods. While widely adopted, conventional heating is often energy intensive and economically inefficient, primarily due to its reliance on surface heat transfer, which leads to uneven and slower internal molecular activation. In contrast, microwave assisted transesterification offers a more efficient alternative by enabling direct interaction of microwave energy with polar molecules within the reaction mixture. This volumetric heating mechanism significantly enhances energy transfer, reduces heat loss, and dramatically shortens reaction times from several hours to just a few minutes thereby improving overall process efficiency and cost effectiveness [14]. The present study advances our previous research on biomass derived sulfonated carbon catalysts [15–17] by demonstrating a simpler, more cost effective, and industrially relevant approach to biodiesel production. Unlike earlier works that employed multistep synthesis involving chemical activation (e.g., ZnCl2 treatment) and aryl diazonium based sulfonation, the current method utilizes a direct hydrothermal carbonization of mango leaves followed by conventional sulfuric acid sulfonation [16,17]. By avoiding specialized reagents and complex processing steps, this route enhances environmental compatibility, reduces material costs, and improves scalability. Furthermore, while our prior studies primarily focused on catalyst surface engineering and activity, this work integrates the use of a widely available and underutilized biowaste (mango leaves) and includes a comprehensive life cycle cost analysis (LCCA). Remarkably, the LCCA revealed a biodiesel production cost of just $0. 203/L–a significant reduction compared to earlier reports ($0.70–1.30/L). Additionally, the use of microwave assisted transesterification enabled a high biodiesel yield (95.1 %) within a short reaction time (56 min) under moderate conditions, with the catalyst retaining substantial activity over five cycles. Collectively, these advancements–streamlined synthesis, economic efficiency, and integration of practical performance metrics–underscore the novelty and industrial potential of the proposed catalytic system for sustainable biodiesel production. In this study, a sulfonated carbonaceous catalyst derived from mango leaves–an abundant and underutilized biowaste–was developed via a simple twostep process involving hydrothermal carbonization followed by direct sulfuric acid sulfonation, and subsequently employed for the acid catalysed transesterification of non-edible Jatropha curcas oil under microwave irradiation. This approach offers a sustainable, low cost, and scalable route to catalyst fabrication, in contrast to previous methods that often involve costly activating agents or complex functionalization steps. The integration of microwave assisted transesterification enabled significant process intensification by reducing both reaction time and energy input, while maintaining a high biodiesel yield. Furthermore, a comprehensive life cycle cost analysis revealed a remarkably low production cost. Collectively, these innovations contribute to the advancement of biomass derived heterogeneous catalysts and present a practical pathway for green and economically viable biodiesel production. 2 Materials and methods 2.1 Chemicals used Mango (Mangifera indica) leaves were gathered from the NIT Silchar campus. Various chemicals used includes H2SO4 (98.07 %), NaHCO3 (≥98.7 %), sodium hydroxide (≥97.8 %), HCl (12 M), phenolphthalein (98 %), BaCl2 (99.95 %), and MeOH (99.8 %). All reagents, along with locally obtained Jatropha curcas oil (JCO), were used directly in the transesterification process without any prior treatment. The molecular weight of the JCO employed in this study was determined to be approximately 900 g mol–1. 2.2 Preparation of catalysts 2.2.1 Preparation of mango leaves based hydrochar The mango leaves were thoroughly cleaned, washed, and dried in an oven for approximately 72 h. They were then cut into smaller pieces and ground into a fine powder using a mixer grinder. In a typical synthesis procedure, 4 g of the powder was mixed with 120 mL of deionized water and transferred into autoclave. The autoclave was then placed in a preheated oven at 180 °C for 24 h. Afterwards, it was removed and allowed to cool to room temperature. The resulting mixture was filtered using a Buchner funnel and dried overnight in an oven at 100 °C. The hydrochar obtained from the mango leaves is referred to as MLHC (mango leaf derived hydrochar). 2.2.2 Preparation of mango leaves based sulphonated carbon catalyst To enhance the catalytic activity of the MLHC, functionalization was carried out using concentrated sulfuric acid, following our previously reported procedure [15]. In this process, biochar was treated with sulfuric acid in a 1:10 (w/v) ratio. To investigate the effect of sulfonation time on catalytic performance, three sets of samples were prepared in pyrex bottles, each containing 1 g of biochar mixed with 10 mL of concentrated sulfuric acid. These were heated at a constant temperature of 80 °C for 12, 15, 18, 21, and 24 h, respectively, in an oven where the MLHC underwent further simultaneous carbonization and sulfonation. Upon completion, the samples were allowed to cool to room temperature, after which they were slowly diluted with 50 mL of deionized water. The resulting mixtures were washed thoroughly using a Büchner funnel until sulphate ions were removed, as confirmed by a qualitative test: the addition of 2–3 drops of 2 M HCl followed by 2–3 drops of BaCl2 to the filtrate, where the absence of a white precipitate indicated complete sulphate removal. The solid residues were then dried in an oven. This mango leaves derived carbonaceous material (MLCM), sulphonated at 80 °C for 12 h is abbreviated as MLCM-12-S. Similarly, the catalysts obtained by sulphonation for 15, 18, 21 and 24 h are respectively abbreviated as MLCM-15-S, MLCM-18-S, MLCM-21-S, and MLCM-24-S. 2.3 Characterization of the catalyst The total acid density of the sulphonated carbon catalysts was measured through neutralization titration using NaOH. For this, 100 mg of the catalyst was stirred with 20 mL of 0.05 M aqueous NaOH at 50 °C for 24 h. The mixture was then purged with argon, followed by filtration to recover the catalyst, which was subsequently washed 2–3 times with deionized water. The filtrate was diluted with 100 mL of deionized water, and a 10 mL aliquot of this solution was titrated against 0.01 M HCl using phenolphthalein as an indicator [18,19]. The materials were characterized using various techniques, including X-ray powder diffraction (XRD), Fourier-transform infrared spectroscopy (FT-IR), scanning electron microscopy (SEM), Brunauer-Emmett-Teller (BET) analysis, and thermogravimetric analysis (TGA). PXRD was conducted with a Miniflex RIGAKU system using CuKα radiation, scanning 2θ from 10° to 90° at an operating voltage of 9 kW to assess crystallinity. SEM, coupled with Energy Dispersive X-ray spectroscopy (EDX), was performed using a JEOL JSM-7600F FEG-SEM, offering SEI resolution of 1.0 nm at 15 kV and 1.5 nm at 1 kV in GB mode, with an acceleration range of 0.1 to 30 kV, to evaluate morphology. TGA was carried out using a METTLER TOLEDO TGA/SDTA851e system from 20 to 900 °C under continuous N2 flow at a heating rate of 5 °C min-1. BET analysis determined total pore volume and surface area. FT-IR spectra were obtained with a Bruker Alpha II FT-IR spectrophotometer using the KBr pellet technique. 2.4 Transesterification of JCO to biodiesel The transesterification reaction was carried out in a microwave reactor using a mixture of JCO, methanol, and the MLCM-18-S catalyst. To optimize the process, key parameters such as the oil to methanol molar ratio (1:12–1:24), reaction temperature (70–110 °C), catalyst loading (3–9 wt.% relative to the oil), and reaction time (32–64 min) were systematically varied. Upon completion, the reaction mixture was centrifuged, and excess methanol was evaporated. The crude product was further purified via aqueous extraction. Catalyst reusability was evaluated, and reaction progression was monitored using thin layer chromatography (TLC). The biodiesel yield was calculated using a standard equation (Eq. (1)), following separation of the catalyst from the product. Also, the methyl ester conversion was calculated using Eq. (2), where A OMe and A C H 2 are the integrals of the methoxy and α-methylene protons, respectively. The transesterification reaction has been schematically represented in Fig. 1 . (1) Biodiesel yield ( % ) = Weight of biodiesel produced Weight of JCO used × 100 (2) Conversion ( % ) = 100 × ( 2 A OMe 3 A C H 2 ) 2.5 Product characterization The product of transesterification, biodiesel, was analysed through gas chromatography and 1H-NMR and 13C-NMR spectroscopy. A Bruker Avance III HD NMR spectrometer (Switzerland) functioning at 500 MHz was utilized to conduct the NMR studies. A gas chromatography mass spectrometry analysis was conducted using an Agilent Technologies 5975C instrument. 2.6 Reaction kinetics In the transesterification of Jatropha curcas oil for biodiesel production, a kinetic model enables the determination of key parameters such as the reaction rate constant and activation energy. This approach provides insight into the reaction mechanism and helps to optimize process conditions. The conversion of triglycerides to fatty acid methyl esters (FAME) is represented by the following stoichiometric equation that captures the essential transformation. (3) TG + ROH ↔ R ′ C O 2 R + DG (4) DG + ROH ↔ R ′ C O 2 R + MG (5) MG + ROH ↔ R ′ C O 2 R + GL In the above processes, MG, DG, TG, and GL represent monoglyceride, diglyceride, triglyceride, and glycerol, respectively. By excluding MG, DG intermediates, the overall single-step reaction can be expressed as shown in Eq. (6) (6) TG + 3 MeOH ↔ 3 R ′ C O 2 R + GL According to the stoichiometric equation, 3 mol of methanol are required to convert 1 mol of triglyceride into fatty acid methyl esters via transesterification. However, due to the reversible nature of the reaction, an excess of methanol is typically used to shift the equilibrium toward product formation. Under these conditions, the methanol concentration is assumed to remain effectively constant, allowing the reaction to be modelled using pseudo first order kinetics. Hence, the rate can be written as (7) Rate = r = − d [ TG ] dt = k [ TG ] Where k, [TG], and t denote the rate constant, TG concentration, and time, respectively. First order rate constants were determined by monitoring conversion over time using Eq. (7) . The activation energy ( E a ) was determined by calculating the rate constants at various temperatures (90–120 °C) and applying the Arrhenius equation (Eq. (9)) to evaluate the temperature dependence of the reaction rate [20]. (8) − ln ( 1 − X ) = kt (9) lnk = E a RT + ln A X, T, and A represent the conversion of JCO (TG) at time t, absolute temperature, and pre-exponential factor, respectively. R is the universal gas constant, 8.314 J K-1 mol-1. 3 Results and discussion 3.1 Effect of sulphonation parameters The biomass to sulfuric acid ratio and sulfonation temperature were carefully selected to maximize catalyst functionalization while preserving structural integrity. A ratio of 1:10 (w/v), based on our earlier findings, provided the highest degree of sulfonation and total acid group density, with a balanced incorporation of sulfonic, carboxylic, and phenolic groups that enhanced catalytic activity [15]. Lower ratios led to insufficient sulfonation, whereas higher ratios caused excessive dehydration and aromatization, resulting in mesopore collapse and reduced active site availability. Similarly, a sulfonation temperature of 80 °C, as supported by literature, offers an optimal balance between structural stability and surface functionalization of carbonaceous catalysts. At this temperature, the carbon framework is sufficiently aromatized to enable effective sulfonic acid grafting while maintaining a loose morphology for high surface accessibility, whereas lower temperatures limit sulfonation efficiency and higher temperatures promote structural degradation and loss of accessible active sites [15]. Following the determination of the optimal biomass to acid ratio and sulfonation temperature, the influence of sulfonation duration was systematically investigated to further optimize the catalyst preparation parameters. To investigate the effect of sulfonation duration on catalytic performance, five mango leaf derived sulfonated carbon catalysts: MLCM-12-S, MLCM-15-S, MLCM-18-S, MLCM-21-S and MLCM-24-S were synthesized by treating hydrochar with concentrated sulfuric acid for 12, 15, 18, 21 and 24 h, respectively. From the neutralization titration the acid density of these five catalysts was respectively found to be 4.84, 5.08, 5.68. 5.44, and 5.32 mmol g–1. The catalyst sulfonated for 18 h exhibited the highest acid density. These catalysts were tested in the transesterification of Jatropha curcas oil under standardized conditions: methanol to oil molar ratio (MOMR) of 21:1, reaction temperature of 90 °C, catalyst loading of 7.5 wt.%, and reaction time of 56 min under microwave irradiation. The biodiesel yields obtained were 82.3 % (MLCM-12-S), 83.5 % (MLCM-15-S), 95.1 % (MLCM-18-S), 94.2 % (MLCM-21-S), and 90.2 % (MLCM-24-S), as shown in Fig. 2a . The superior performance of MLCM-18-S indicates that 18 h of sulfonation is optimal, likely because it facilitates sufficient incorporation of –SO3H groups without over carbonization or structural degradation. Shorter sulfonation (12 h, 15 h) may lead to incomplete functionalization, while prolonged treatment (18 h, 24 h) could cause pore collapse or excessive charring, reducing the catalyst’s surface reactivity [21,22]. Accordingly, MLCM-18-S, exhibiting the highest acid density, was chosen for subsequent characterization and process optimization. 3.2 Catalyst characterization 3.2.1 Powder XRD analysis A comparative analysis of the XRD patterns of mango leaves, MLHC, and MLCM-18-S highlights the progressive structural transformation induced by carbonization and functionalization. MLCM displayed multiple diffraction peaks at approximately 2θ ≈ 14.9, 22.4, 24.3, 29.9, 35.8, 38.0, 39.7, and 43.5°. These features are consistent with the hydrothermally derived carbonaceous materials reported by Falco et al. [23], thereby confirming the successful partial carbonization and structural transformation of the biomass during hydrothermal treatment. MLCM-18-S, exhibits broad and diffuse peaks in the 2θ range of 19–30° and 40–50°, as shown in Fig. 2b. These features correspond to the (002) and (101) diffraction planes of disordered carbon, respectively, confirming the presence of predominantly amorphous carbon with limited graphitic domains [24]. The broadening and reduced intensity of these peaks are indicative of disordered graphitic carbon structures with low crystallinity. This structural disorder arises from the incorporation of functional groups such as –SO3H, –COOH, and –OH groups onto polycyclic aromatic carbon sheets during sulfonation, which further enhances the amorphous nature of the catalyst [16]. 3.2.2 FT-IR analysis Fourier Transform Infrared (FTIR) analysis was conducted to identify the surface functional groups of the materials as depicted in Fig. 2c. All the three materials have a broad peak near 3400 cm-1 showing the presence of –OH group. MLCM-18-S have a prominent peak around 1692 cm-1 corresponding to C=O stretching vibrations that indicates the presence of carbonyl functionalities. The band at 1612 cm-1 present in MLHC, MLCM-18-S is attributed to C=C skeletal stretching of aromatic domains, characteristic of partially graphitized carbon structures. Successful sulfonation in MLCM-18-S was confirmed by the appearance of peaks at 1165 and 1019 cm-1, which correspond to the asymmetric stretching of O=S=O and the symmetric stretching of –SO3 – groups, respectively, confirming the incorporation of sulfonic acid groups (–SO3H) onto the carbon surface [15,25]. Additionally, the band near 1019 cm-1 is also associated with C–S stretching vibrations, further validating the sulfonation process [17]. These findings align with previous reports demonstrating that sulfonated carbons exhibit strong S=O and C–S bands post functionalization, confirming the successful introduction of –SO3H groups [21,17]. 3.2.3 SEM-EDX analysis The detailed morphology of the MLCM-18-S catalyst has been discussed as represented in Fig. 3a, b . The SEM analysis of the sulfonated carbon catalyst prepared via hydrothermal treatment reveals an irregular and aggregated morphology. This irregularity is primarily due to water loss during the hydrothermal treatment process, which leads to particle shrinkage and aggregation. The catalyst exhibits a heterogeneous and porous surface morphology, which is particularly advantageous for catalytic applications. The roughened texture and interconnected pore network significantly increase the effective surface area, thereby providing a greater number of accessible active sites for the adsorption of methanol and triglyceride molecules, even under microwave assisted conditions. This structural arrangement enhances mass transfer efficiency between reactants and sulfonic groups, leading to accelerated transesterification kinetics. Collectively, these morphological attributes, together with the high density of surface functional groups, underpin the superior catalytic activity and biodiesel yield achieved with the prepared catalyst. The elemental mapping of the MLCM-18-S catalyst showed homogenous presence of carbon, oxygen and sulphur as displayed in Fig. 3d–f. Elemental analysis revealed distinct compositional changes during the stepwise transformation of mango peel into a sulfonated carbonaceous catalyst. The raw mango peel (Fig. 3h) contained 48.6 % carbon and 45.4 % oxygen, reflecting the typical composition of lignocellulosic biomass rich in cellulose, hemicellulose, and lignin. Following hydrothermal carbonization, the carbon content increased markedly to 62.4 % while oxygen decreased to 32.2 % (Fig. 3i), indicating dehydration and decarboxylation reactions that remove oxygen containing functional groups (–OH, –COOH) and enrich the carbon framework through aromatization. Subsequent sulfonation with concentrated sulfuric acid introduced sulfur functionalities, as evidenced by the 7.4 % sulfur content, while the carbon and oxygen contents adjusted to 59.6 % and 33.0 %, respectively. The excellent catalytic activity of the catalyst can be attributed in part to its high surface acidity. The sulphur content of the MLCM-18-S catalyst was substantially higher than the 4.7 wt.% in our previous study [15], indicating a greater density of –SO3H groups. This high density of acidic functional groups compensates for limitations in surface area or pore structure by providing readily accessible active sites for transesterification. 3.2.4 TGA analysis The mango leaf, MLHC and MLCM-18-S was evaluated using thermogravimetric analysis (TGA) from room temperature up to 840 °C as presented in Fig. 4a .The TGA of raw mango leaf and MLHC reveal distinct thermal degradation stages associated with moisture loss, decomposition of organic constituents, and structural breakdown. The initial weight loss below ∼160 °C (4.97 % for mango leaf and 3.83 % for MLHC) is attributed to the evaporation of physically adsorbed and weakly bound moisture. In the second stage, extending up to ∼470 °C, the raw mango leaf experienced greater weight loss (54.49 %) compared to MLHC (40.16 %), which can be ascribed to the decomposition of hemicellulose, cellulose, and other volatile organics present in higher proportions in the untreated biomass. Hydrothermal treatment partially carbonizes the material, reducing labile oxygenated functionalities and enriching the carbon content, thereby improving thermal resistance. At higher temperatures, the reduced degradation of MLHC in the third and fourth stages reflects the presence of a more condensed and aromatized carbon framework, generated during hydrothermal carbonization, which resists further decomposition compared to the raw biomass. The TGA profile of MLCM-18-S revealed three major stages of weight loss, each corresponding to distinct thermal events. An initial 2.67 % weight loss up to 100 °C was observed, attributed to the evaporation of physically adsorbed moisture. This indicates that the catalyst maintains structural integrity well within the operational temperature range of transesterification, which was conducted below 100 °C. The second stage, with a 7.03 % weight loss up to 179 °C, corresponds to the partial decomposition of surface bound sulfonic acid groups (–SO3H) [15,24]. Importantly, this temperature range remains above the reaction conditions employed in the present study, ensuring that the catalytic active sites remain intact during biodiesel production. The final and most substantial weight loss of 38.82 % up to 840 °C is associated with the degradation of the carbonaceous framework [15,24]. The presence of a robust carbon structure up to high temperatures confirms that MLCM-18-S possesses sufficient thermal stability for catalytic applications, further validating its effectiveness and durability during the transesterification of Jatropha curcas oil. 3.2.5 BET analysis BET analysis as displayed in Fig. 4b and 4c demonstrates the progressive structural transformation of mango leaves during hydrothermal carbonization and sulfonation. The raw biomass exhibited a very low surface area (0.625 m2 g–1) and negligible pore volume (0.001 cc g–1), reflecting its dense lignocellulosic framework. Table 1 shows that hydrothermal carbonization led to a notable increase in surface area (5.163 m2 g–1), pore volume (0.010 cc g–1), and average pore diameter (7.307 nm), signifying partial decomposition of the biomass matrix and the formation of a more porous carbon structure. Upon sulfonation (MLCM-18-S), both surface area (2.897 m2 g–1) and pore volume (0.004 cc g–1) decreased slightly, accompanied by a reduction in average pore diameter (5.884 nm). This decline can be attributed to the introduction of –SO3H and other oxygenated functional groups, which may block a fraction of pores and reduce overall surface accessibility. The nitrogen adsorption–desorption isotherm of MLCM-18-S approximately follows a Type IV profile as shown in Fig. 4b, characterized by the presence of a hysteresis loop, indicating mesoporous behaviour with capillary condensation in the pores [15]. In the pore size distribution (PSD) analysis a sharp peak at ∼1.8 nm corresponds to micropores, while an additional distribution around ∼5 nm and a minor tail extending to ∼16 nm confirms mesopores and small macropores further confirming the presence of a hierarchical pore network. Although the BET surface area (2.89 m2 g–1) is relatively low compared to conventional mesoporous adsorbents, the average pore diameter derived from BJH analysis (5.8 nm) reflects the greater contribution of mesopores to the total pore volume. This bimodal micro mesoporous structure is particularly advantageous, as it combines the adsorption capacity of micropores with the improved molecular transport and reduced diffusion resistance offered by meso/macropores. Collectively, these characteristics, combined with the introduction of strong acidic sites, significantly enhance the catalytic potential of the sulfonated carbon catalyst for biodiesel synthesis. Despite the relatively low BET surface area and pore volume of MLCM-18-S, the catalyst delivered an excellent biodiesel yield of 95.1 %. This superior activity is primarily ascribed to its high acid site density (7.40 wt.% of S), which provides abundant –SO3H groups essential for transesterification. In solid acid catalysis, the density and accessibility of active sites often play a more decisive role than surface area. Moreover, the moderate mesoporosity and functionalized surface facilitated effective reactant–catalyst interactions, while microwave assisted conditions further promoted mass transfer, together accounting for the outstanding catalytic efficiency observed. 3.3 Product characterization 3.3.1 NMR analysis The transesterification of JCO to biodiesel using the MLCM-18-S catalyst was confirmed through 1H-NMR and 13C-NMR as shown in Fig. 5a and 5b. In the 1H-NMR spectrum, the singlet at 3.69 ppm corresponds to the methoxy protons (–OCH3), while the triplet at 2.32 ppm is attributed to α-methylene protons (–αCH2–COO–), both confirming the formation of fatty acid methyl esters (FAMEs) [26,27]. Peaks in the region 0.88–0.92 ppm are assigned to terminal methyl protons (–CH3), and those in the 1.27–2.08 ppm range represent methylene protons of the long alkyl chain. The peak at 5.36 ppm indicates olefinic protons, suggesting the presence of unsaturated chains [28]. The methyl ester conversion was calculated using Eq. (2), where A OMe and A C H 2 are the integrals of the methoxy and α-methylene protons, respectively, yielding a conversion of 96.61 %. The 13C-NMR spectrum (Fig. 5b) further validates the product’s structure. The signal at 174.35 ppm corresponds to the ester carbonyl carbon (–COO–), while the peak at 51.46 ppm confirms the methoxy carbon. Additional signals at 14.13 ppm and between 24.96–34.11 ppm are attributed to terminal methyl and methylene carbons of the fatty acid chains, respectively [29,30]. These spectral features confirm the successful synthesis of biodiesel with high purity. 3.3.2 FT-IR analysis The FTIR spectra of JCO and the corresponding biodiesel as displayed in Fig. 6a reveal significant spectral changes, confirming successful transesterification. A key shift is observed in the carbonyl stretching band from 1743 cm–1 in JCO to 1736 cm–1 in the biodiesel, indicating the conversion of triglycerides to methyl esters. The peak at 3003 cm–1 in the biodiesel corresponds to =C–H stretching of unsaturated esters. Peaks at 2921 and 2850 cm–1 represent asymmetric and symmetric C–H stretching of methylene groups. New bands in the biodiesel spectrum at 1431 and 1190 cm–1 suggest bending vibrations of –CH2 and C–O stretching, respectively. The presence of peaks at 1112, 1016, and 803 cm–1 can be attributed to C–O stretching and out of plane C–H bending of esters. Additionally, distinct bands at 661 and 612 cm–1 likely arise from wagging and rocking modes of long chain hydrocarbon groups. These spectral features collectively confirm the successful synthesis of biodiesel. 3.3.3 Gas chromatography The fatty acid methyl ester (FAME) composition of the biodiesel produced from JCO using the MLCM-18-S catalyst was determined through gas chromatography (GC) analysis. As presented in Table 2 and Fig. 6b, the predominant component was methyl oleate (C18:1), accounting for 57.36 %, followed by methyl palmitate (C16:0, 13.20 %) and methyl stearate (C18:0, 11.46 %). The high content of oleic acid methyl ester contributes significantly to the oxidative stability of the biodiesel, enhancing its storage and performance characteristics [31]. Additional minor constituents include methyl linoleate (C18:2, 2.68 %), methyl eicosanoate (C20:0, 5.43 %), and methyl nonadecenoate (C19:1, 5.93 %), further reflect the diverse lipid profile of JCO and collectively modulate the fuel’s balance between cold-flow behavior and oxidative resistance. The proportion of unsaturated FAMEs (C18:1, C18:2, C19:1) was found to be higher than saturated FAMEs (C16:0, C18:0, C20:0), indicating good cold flow properties while retaining reasonable oxidative resistance. This balance is directly reflected in the ASTM-tested properties of the synthesized biodiesel as represented in Section 3.3.4. This FAME distribution is consistent with literature reports on JCO derived biodiesel [16,32]. Variations in the fatty acid profile can be attributed to agro climatic factors affecting Jatropha cultivation. Thus, using JCO not only provides a sustainable biodiesel feedstock but also avoids competition with food resources, supporting environmental and economic viability [31]. 3.3.4 Physicochemical properties of JCO and the product biodiesel According to ASTM guidelines, the physicochemical characteristics of the biodiesel made using the MLCM-18-S catalyst were evaluated and compared with the feedstock JCO (Table 3 ). The biodiesel is suitable to handle, store, and transport, with a flash point of 159 °C. It was discovered that the density, a crucial factor affecting engine performance was 0.86 g cm–3. The pour point was measured at 3.43 °C, confirming that the fuel retains sufficient fluidity under moderately low temperatures, while the high oleate content underpins oxidative stability and storage safety. The generated biodiesel’s potential as a dependable alternative fuel was confirmed when the cetane number, a measure of combustion quality, was discovered to be 56.0 falling within the recommended standard range. The permissible value of the kinematic viscosity also underscores its critical role in maintaining efficient fuel flow, especially under low-temperature conditions. Thus, the GC–MS profile along with the physio chemical properties confirms efficient JCO conversion to biodiesel and directly correlates with its favourable physicochemical properties meeting ASTM standards. The oleate-rich composition, balanced with saturated and polyunsaturated esters, highlights the effectiveness of the MLCM-18-S catalyst in producing high-quality, sustainable biodiesel. 3.4 Optimization of microwave assisted transesterification parameters for Jatropha curcas oil To achieve high yield biodiesel production, key parameters, including the oil to methanol molar ratio (1:12–1:24), reaction temperature (70–110 °C), catalyst loading (3–9 wt.% relative to the oil), and reaction time (32–64 min) were optimized using a single factor optimization approach. The selected ranges were established based on previously reported literature, ensuring that the conditions remained within experimentally validated and practically relevant limits [17,10]. These ranges made it possible to explore both the lower and upper limits of each parameter, helping to determine the conditions that not only maximize conversion efficiency but also remain practical for the process. The reactions were conducted under microwave irradiation, and the effects of the key parameters are summarized in both Table 4 and Fig. 7 . 3.4.1 Effect of methanol to oil molar ratio In the transesterification reaction, methanol is used instead of higher alcohols because higher alcohols decrease the efficiency of biodiesel conversion, reduce lubricity, and negatively affect biodiesel's fuel properties. Methanol offers several physical and chemical advantages over higher alcohols, including its higher polarity, which enables it to react more swiftly with triglycerides [33]. The molar ratio between JCO and methanol is a critical factor that significantly influences the yield of methyl esters. The effect of MOMR was studied at different MOMR of 12:1–24:1 and the other variables were fixed (temperature of 90 °C, 56 min reaction time, 7.5 wt.% catalyst) as shown in Fig. 7a. Transesterification is a reversible reaction. In order to move the reaction to the right, extra methanol is therefore needed. Highest yield was obtained when MOMR was 21:1 which slightly decreased with further addition of methanol. The biodiesel yield increased from 45.6 % at 12:1 to a maximum of 95.1 % at 21:1. The conversion of JCO was not sufficient at low MOMR but it increased as more amount of methanol was added. These findings show that extra methanol should be added for larger production of JCO biodiesel with optimum yield obtained from MOMR of 21:1 [34]. Excess methanol can dissolve glycerol (the byproduct of transesterification) and the backward reaction may happen impairing the reaction between the methanol with the catalyst and the oil, because of which beyond MOMR 21:1, the yield was found to decrease [35,36]. 3.4.2 Effect of reaction temperature Transesterification of triglycerides using a solid catalyst presents mass transfer limitations due to the heterogeneous nature of the system, which involves immiscible reactants distributed across three phases methanol, oil, and solid catalyst [37]. Increasing the reaction temperature can effectively reduce this interfacial diffusion resistance by enhancing molecular mobility and promoting better phase interaction. In this study, the effect of reaction temperature on biodiesel yield was investigated over the range of 60–100 °C under fixed conditions: methanol to oil molar ratio (MOMR) of 21:1, catalyst loading of 7.5 wt.%, and a reaction time of 56 min (Fig. 7b). Since transesterification is an endothermic reaction, increasing the reaction temperature generally enhances the conversion by supplying the required activation energy. As illustrated in Fig. 7b, raising the temperature from 60 to 90 °C led to a progressive increase in biodiesel yield, with an optimum yield achieved at 90 °C. Elevated temperatures promote better miscibility among the immiscible phases containing oil, methanol, and catalyst; by enhancing molecular motion and collision frequency [37]. However, beyond 90 °C, the yield plateaued due to methanol's tendency to volatilize at higher temperatures, which diminishes its effective concentration in the reaction medium and hinders conversion [37,38]. This trend aligns with previous literature reports [39], confirming 90 °C as the optimal reaction temperature for maximum biodiesel yield. 3.4.3 Effect of catalyst loading The catalyst plays a pivotal role in the transesterification process, directly influencing the efficiency and cost effectiveness of biodiesel production. To assess the effect of catalyst loading, the reaction was conducted at a MOMR of 21:1, 90 °C, and 56 min, varying the catalyst concentration from 3 to 9 wt.% (Fig. 7c). As the catalyst loading increased from 3 to 7.5 wt.%, the biodiesel yield improved significantly from 61.3 % to 95.1 %, primarily due to the enhanced availability of active sites and surface area [40]. However, further increasing the catalyst loading beyond 7.5 wt.% resulted in a decline in yield. This reduction can be attributed to increased viscosity of the reaction medium, leading to poor dispersion, restricted mass transfer, and a higher likelihood of saponification reactions, which hinder phase separation and reduce the overall conversion efficiency [41]. Additionally, the onset of mass transfer limitations between reactants and catalyst may also contribute to the observed decrease in yield [40]. 3.4.4 Effect of reaction time Reaction time is a crucial parameter in transesterification, as it governs the extent to which triglycerides are converted into methyl esters. As shown in Fig. 7d, the biodiesel yield increased significantly from 32 to 56 min, indicating progressive conversion of the oil. Beyond 56 min, the yield plateaued, suggesting that the reaction had reached equilibrium. The use of microwave irradiation in the reaction system provides localized superheating and rapid internal heating, which enhances the diffusivity of reactants and reduces boundary layer resistance. This compensates for any potential limitations in pore connectivity or volume, ensuring effective interaction between the reactants and active sites. The maximum yield of 95.1 % was obtained at 56 min, which was thus identified as the optimal reaction time. Prolonged reaction times beyond this point do not contribute to further conversion and may lead to undesired side reactions such as saponification [42,43]. 3.5 Comparison with conventional heating To validate the effectiveness of microwave assisted transesterification, a parallel reaction was conducted under conventional heating using the same optimized conditions (methanol to oil molar ratio of 21:1, catalyst loading of 7.5 wt.%, and temperature of 90 °C). The reaction carried out under conventional heating yielded 32.4 % biodiesel after 56 min, which is significantly lower than the 95.1 % yield obtained under microwave irradiation. Despite the same bulk temperature, the microwave assisted process demonstrated superior efficiency, likely due to rapid volumetric heating, localized superheating, and enhanced mass transfer, consistent with reported microwave specific (non-thermal) effects [44]. A similar enhancement in biodiesel yield under microwave irradiation was reported by Gupta and Rathod [45], where calcium diglyceroxide catalyzed transesterification of waste cooking oil achieved a yield of 94.86 % using microwave heating, in contrast to only 42.59 % under conventional conditions. In another study, a ZrO2/bamboo leaf ash (BLA) catalyst produced 80.5 % biodiesel from rice bran oil within just 30 min under microwave irradiation, whereas conventional heating yielded only 50.15 % even after 2 h, demonstrating the efficiency of microwave assisted transesterification [46]. Another study employing a KOH/γ-Al2O3 catalyst demonstrated that microwave assisted transesterification significantly reduced the reaction time from 3 h to just 35 min, while achieving a comparable methyl ester yield of approximately 97.3 %, highlighting the efficiency of microwave irradiation over conventional heating [47]. These findings underscore the advantages of microwave heating in intensifying the transesterification process by reducing energy consumption and reaction time, due to microwave specific effects such as dipolar polarization and localized superheating, which enhance reaction kinetics and mass transfer. 3.6 Analysis of the reaction kinetics involved in transesterification The kinetics of the transesterification reaction for biodiesel production from JCO using the synthesized MLCM-18-S catalyst was investigated at varying temperatures of 60, 70, 80, and 90 °C as illustrated in Fig. 8a and 8b The reaction conditions were maintained at a methanol to oil molar ratio (MOMR) of 21:1 and a catalyst loading of 7.5 wt.%, with reaction durations ranging from 32 to 64 min. A significant enhancement in reaction rate was observed with the application of the heterogeneous catalyst compared to non-catalysed systems. The kinetic data were analysed by plotting –ln(1–X) against time, where X represents the fractional conversion of JCO. The linearity of these plots confirmed that the reaction follows pseudo first order kinetics with respect to triglyceride concentration. The corresponding rate constants (k) were calculated for each temperature and subsequently used to construct an Arrhenius plot of ln k versus 1/T. From the slope and intercept of this plot, the activation energy (Ea) and pre exponential factor (A) was estimated to be 16.53 kJ mol–1 and 20.28 min–1, respectively. These values are consistent with those reported for similar transesterification systems employing biomass derived solid acid catalysts, demonstrating the catalytic efficiency and thermal stability of MLCM-18-S [48–50]. 3.7 Heterogeneity and reusability studies of catalyst For a catalyst to be truly heterogeneous and cost effective in biodiesel production, it must exhibit minimal leaching of active components into the reaction medium [51]. To assess the heterogeneity and stability of the MLCM-18-S catalyst, a leaching test was performed as illustrated in Fig. 9a [52]. The catalyst was removed after 40 min of reaction, at which point the biodiesel yield had reached 80.6 %. The reaction was allowed to proceed without the catalyst until 72 min, resulting in a marginal yield increase to 82.5 %. This minimal change (1.9 %) indicates that no significant catalytic activity persisted in the absence of the solid catalyst. If the catalyst had leached active species into the reaction medium, a continued increase in yield would be expected. Therefore, the negligible post removal activity confirms the absence of soluble active species and reinforces the catalyst's heterogeneous nature and structural stability under reaction conditions. Heterogeneous catalysts are widely employed in industrial processes due to their ability to be recovered and reused, thereby improving process efficiency and economic viability. In this study, the reusability of the MLCM-18-S catalyst was assessed over five consecutive cycles under optimized reaction conditions: MOMR of 21:1, a reaction time of 56 min, a temperature of 90 °C, and a catalyst loading of 7.5 wt. %. Following each reaction cycle, the catalyst was separated by filtration to remove adsorbed reactants and products, subsequently regenerated by sequential washing with hexane, methanol, and chloroform, and dried in an oven at 80 °C for 5 h. The regenerated catalyst was then reused in subsequent transesterification reactions. The reaction progress was monitored using thin layer chromatography (TLC) and gas chromatography (GC). Catalysts derived from waste sources such as MPANI@Co3O4 [53] and RS-SO3H [54] also achieved yields above 90 %, yet required longer reaction times (240 and 360 min, respectively), which may limit their industrial applicability. The CaO(12)/rGO catalyst [55], though effective (91.0 % yield), also required higher catalyst loading (9.9 wt.%) and extended reaction duration. In contrast, the MLCM-18-S catalyst developed in the present study delivered a high biodiesel yield of 96.6 % under comparatively mild conditions: a methanol to oil molar ratio of 21:1, catalyst loading of 7.5 wt.%, temperature of 90 °C, and a short reaction time of 56 min. These results indicate that MLCM-18-S offers an optimal combination of high catalytic efficiency, lower energy requirement, and operational simplicity, making it a strong candidate for efficient and scalable biodiesel production As shown in Fig. 9b, the catalyst maintained a high level of activity over multiple runs, with only a slight reduction in biodiesel yield, which decreased to 81.3 % by the fifth run. This gradual decline in performance was attributed to the accumulation of organic residues on the catalyst surface. Elemental analysis of the reused catalyst via EDX analysis (Fig. 9c) showed a minor reduction in sulphur content, from 7.4 wt.% in the fresh catalyst to 5.22 wt.% after five runs, which may have contributed to the observed decline in catalytic activity. 3.8 Comparison of present MLCM-18-S catalyst with other reported heterogeneous catalysts Several heterogeneous catalysts have been reported for biodiesel production using various feedstocks under differing reaction conditions. Table 5a presents a comparative analysis of selected catalysts, including their feedstock types, operational parameters, and biodiesel yields, to assess the performance of the developed MLCM-18-S catalyst. Our previously reported catalysts BPAC-500-S [17] and SAFACAM [56] achieved excellent biodiesel yields (97.1 % and 98.7 %, respectively), although BPAC-500-S required a high methanol to oil molar ratio of 22.4:1 and SAFACAM operated at 120 °C. Similarly, the eggshell-moringa leaf catalyst [57] provided a 94.3 % yield but required a longer reaction time of 78 min. On the other hand, HPW-HSAG500 [58] and Amberlyst A26 (OH) [59] demonstrated lower yields (31.1 % and 36.3 %, respectively), indicating reduced catalytic efficiency despite prolonged reaction durations or high reactant ratios. Catalysts derived from waste sources such as MPANI@Co3O4 [53] and RS-SO3H [54] also achieved yields above 90 %, yet required longer reaction times (240 and 360 min, respectively), which may limit their industrial applicability. The CaO(12)/rGO catalyst [55], though effective (91.0 % yield), also required higher catalyst loading (9.9 wt.%) and extended reaction duration. In contrast, the MLCM-18-S catalyst developed in the present study delivered a high biodiesel yield of 96.6 % under comparatively mild conditions: a methanol to oil molar ratio of 21:1, catalyst loading of 7.5 wt.%, temperature of 90 °C, and a short reaction time of 56 min. These results indicate that MLCM-18-S offers an optimal combination of high catalytic efficiency, lower energy requirement, and operational simplicity, making it a strong candidate for efficient and scalable biodiesel production. A critical comparison with previously reported carbonaceous catalysts as displayed in Table 5b reveals that most require energy intensive pyrolysis steps, often at elevated temperatures under inert atmospheres such as nitrogen or argon, which substantially increases production costs and environmental burden. For example, HC-KOH derived from coconut endocarp required 10 h to achieve 92.7 % biodiesel [60]. OSB-SO3H from olive stones utilized costly argon during pyrolysis [61] and potato peel pyrolyzed calcined biochar catalyst (PPBC) involved sequential pyrolysis and calcination [62]. Other catalysts employed multistep syntheses combining high temperature carbonization and sulfonation [63], incorporated expensive or corrosive reagents such as iron chloride and concentrated sulfuric acid [64–66] or required carbonization temperatures as high as 750 °C [67]. The majority of the reported studies also employed comparatively prolonged reaction time [60,62,63,65–67]. In contrast, the MLCM-18-S catalyst developed in the present study attains a high biodiesel yield of 95.1 % from JCO under comparatively mild preparation and reaction conditions (90 °C, 56 min), without the need for costly inert gases or multi stage thermal treatments, thereby offering a more economically viable and operationally sustainable alternative. 3.9 Bibliometric studies To contextualize the present study within the broader research landscape, a bibliometric analysis was conducted using data extracted from 200 Scopus indexed publications published over the last decade, as displayed in Fig. 10 . The search was performed using relevant keywords including biodiesel, transesterification, cost analysis, sulphonation, and carbonaceous material. The data were visualized using VOSviewer, which generated a cooccurrence network map where each node represents a keyword, the node size indicates its frequency of occurrence, and the links between nodes represent the strength of their cooccurrence. The resulting map reveals biodiesel as the most dominant and central term, indicating its critical role in the research corpus. It is closely associated with key terms such as transesterification, biofuel, catalyst, and heterogeneous catalyst, underscoring the centrality of catalytic processes in biodiesel production. The green cluster predominantly represents research focused on catalyst development and process optimization, including methodologies such as response surface methodology. The blue cluster centres around feedstock related terms such as waste cooking oil, methanol, and fatty acid methyl ester, reflecting ongoing interest in renewable and low cost raw materials. The red cluster is aligned with environmental sustainability themes, prominently featuring carbon capture and utilization, biomass, pyrolysis, and activated carbon; areas directly relevant to the present study involving a sulphonated carbonaceous catalyst derived from mango leaves. This bibliometric mapping highlights the interdisciplinary nature of current biodiesel research and positions the present work at the intersection of green chemistry, sustainable energy, and catalytic material development, thus contributing meaningfully to the evolving discourse on renewable biofuels. 3.10 Life cycle cost analysis Life Cycle Cost Analysis (LCCA) is an essential tool to assess the economic viability of biodiesel production by accounting for costs associated with raw material usage, catalyst synthesis, reaction processes, and operational reusability. In this study, LCCA was performed to estimate the production cost of 1 L of biodiesel using JCO as the feedstock and the synthesized MLCM-18-S catalyst. The analysis was based on laboratory scale quantities and local market prices as of April 2025. The expenses of chemicals, electricity were converted to US dollars ($) from Indian Rupees (INR). As detailed in Table 6a , the total cost of catalyst preparation (67.82 g) was calculated to be 0.39 $, including chemical costs (sulfuric acid), and the costs for hydrothermal treatment, sulphonation, and washing steps. Given its effective reuse over five cycles, the cost per use was reduced to 0.078 $. For biodiesel production (Table 6b ), methanol consumption and the feedstock (JCO) respectively contributed 0.078 $ and 0.009 $ while the energy cost for the 56 min transesterification reaction amounted to 0.027 $. An additional 10 % overhead charge was applied, resulting in a total estimated production cost of 0.203 $ per litre of biodiesel. Though this laboratory scale cost may not precisely reflect large scale industrial economics, it provides a practical benchmark. The production cost was lower than many of the reported literature such as 0.678 $/kg in soybean oil biodiesel [70], 1.3 $/kg in JCO biodiesel [16], 0.37 $/kg in JCO biodiesel [24]. The low catalyst and process costs, combined with efficient reusability, demonstrate the economic potential of MLCM-18-S for sustainable biodiesel production and support its further exploration in scale up studies. A full scale cost model would need to include additional factors such as feedstock collection logistics, infrastructure, labour, and process scale up parameters, which are beyond the scope of this work. However, the presented LCCA highlights the economic viability of the catalyst under efficient reuse conditions, making it a promising candidate for future techno economic assessments. 4 Conclusion The present study demonstrates an effective, scalable, and ecofriendly strategy for biodiesel production using a sulfonated carbonaceous catalyst (MLCM-18-S) derived from mango leaves, an abundant lignocellulosic biowaste. The catalyst was synthesized via a simple twostep process involving hydrothermal carbonization and sulfuric acid sulfonation, eliminating the need for costly chemical activators and enabling an environmentally compatible synthesis route. Elemental and morphological analyses revealed a progressive transformation from raw mango leaf (48.6 % C, 45.4 % O) to hydrochar (62.4 % C, 32.2 % O) and finally to the sulfonated catalyst (59.6 % C, 33.0 % O, 7.4 % S), where the introduction of –SO3H groups and the development of a porous heterogeneous surface collectively enhanced active site availability, accounting for the superior catalytic efficiency in biodiesel synthesis. Process intensification through microwave assisted transesterification significantly reduced the reaction time to just 56 min while maintaining a high biodiesel yield of 95.1 % under optimized conditions. The catalyst exhibited excellent reusability, retaining 81.3 % yield after five cycles, and its true heterogeneity was confirmed by Sheldon’s test. Importantly, a detailed life cycle cost analysis revealed a remarkably low production cost of $ 0.203 per litre of biodiesel highlighting the process’s economic viability. While these estimates are based on laboratory scale inputs and simplified assumptions, they provide a foundational understanding of the catalyst’s potential economic performance. Further scale up studies and comprehensive techno economic modelling will be essential to validate these findings under industrial conditions. These combined innovations in catalyst design, energy efficient processing, and cost effective operation position this work as a promising step toward industrial scale implementation of sustainable biodiesel technologies. coredata.dc:description: Growing concerns over fossil fuel depletion and environmental impact have intensified the search for sustainable biofuels such as biodiesel. To address the drawbacks of homogeneous catalysts, a novel heterogeneous catalyst (MLCM-18-S) was developed via hydrothermal carbonization of mango leaf powder followed by sulfonation. This carbonaceous catalyst was employed for biodiesel production from non-edible Jatropha curcas oil. Under optimized conditions (methanol to oil ratio 21:1, 90 °C, 7.5 wt. % catalyst, 56 min of microwave irradiation), a high yield of 95.1 % biodiesel was achieved. The catalyst was thoroughly characterized using FTIR, XRD, SEM, BET and TGA, while the biodiesel was analysed by FTIR, NMR, and GC-MS. TGA demonstrated improved stability after hydrothermal treatment of mango leaf (weight loss reduced from 54.5 % to 40.2 % up to 470 °C), while the sulfonated catalyst (MLCM-18-S) showed only 7.0 % loss of –SO3H groups below 180 °C, confirming structural integrity under biodiesel reaction conditions. BET analysis confirmed the structural evolution from raw mango leaves (0.62 m2 g–1, 0.001 cc g–1), to a porous hydrochar (5.16 m2 g–1, 0.010 cc g–1), while sulfonation yielded a micro–mesoporous catalyst (MLCM-18-S) with hierarchical pores (∼1.8–16 nm) and abundant –SO3H groups. Kinetic studies revealed pseudo first order behaviour with an activation energy of 16.53 kJ mol–1. The catalyst exhibited excellent stability, retaining high activity up to the 5th reuse cycle. This study highlights the effectiveness of sustainable biomass derived catalysts for efficient and economically viable biodiesel production.
